author: By Gary Santaniello
title: He Has Worked With Both Stanley Cup Coaches. Who Is He Rooting For?
description: George Gwozdecky, a former Lightning assistant, once worked with Tampa Bay’s coach, Jon Cooper, and Dallas’s, Rick Bowness.
content: This year’s Stanley Cup finals features two head coaches who are very familiar with each other: The Dallas Stars’ interim coach, Rick Bowness, was an assistant for the Lightning’s coach, Jon Cooper, for five years at Tampa Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Desmond
title: How Trump’s Race-Baiting Lets Liberals Off the Hook
description: It’s easy to condemn the president’s rhetoric about the suburbs. But white progressives play their own roles in keeping communities segregated.
content: On the last day of August, the Fox News host Laura Ingraham interviewed President Trump on her show, “The Ingraham Angle.” Five weeks earlier, Trump endured a half-hour interview with the Axios political reporter Jonathan Swan, who grilled Trump about Covid-19 with the kind of disdain economics professors reserve for a graduate student who botches the calculation. Ingraham was the anti-Swan, fawning and pat. Leaning forward in her chair with a warm expression, she tossed softballs and gently guided the president back on track when he veered into politically risky territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $725,000 Homes in Kentucky, Missouri and Minnesota
description: An 1840 Greek Revival home near Louisville, a midcentury-modern house in Springfield and a Gothic-Tudor cottage in Minneapolis.
content: Built by a New Orleans family believed to have moved to Kentucky to escape a yellow-fever epidemic, this house was bought in 1867 by the Confederate Army general Edmund Kirby Smith, who ran a military school on the grounds. (Remnants of the barracks foundation remain.) The house, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, has been in the family of the current owner since 1933. It has been restored, with all systems thoroughly modernized, and was recently operated as a lodging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Trump Turns Attack on MSNBC Journalist Into Rally Fodder
description: At multiple campaign stops, the president has gotten laughs by inaccurately recounting Ali Velshi’s being hit by a rubber bullet while covering a protest.
content: Claims of “fake news” have long been a staple of President Trump’s rally speeches. But in recent days, with the election less than six weeks off, he has made his rhetorical attacks on the news media more personal, with repeated references to a specific reporter’s suffering an injury while on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: ‘Vote or Die’ T-shirts are back, with a twist.
description: Pyer Moss, a Black-owned fashion label, released a limited-edition run of “Vote or Die … For Real This Time” T-shirts on Tuesday, a re-imagination of the original shirts that debuted in 2004 by Sean Combs’s brand Sean John.
content: Pyer Moss, a Black-owned fashion label, released a limited-edition run of “Vote or Die … For Real This Time” T-shirts on Tuesday, a re-imagination of the original shirts that debuted in 2004 by Sean Combs’s brand Sean John.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘A Wilderness of Error’ Review: Errol Morris in the Fog of Murder
description: The famous documentary maker sits on the other side of the camera to offer his own take on the Jeffrey R. MacDonald murder case.
content: “A Wilderness of Error” is not, technically, a new Errol Morris documentary. But the five-part FX series (premiering with three episodes on Friday) begins with a clapperboard in front of Morris’s face, and he’s the star of the show, as well as its secondary subject and, perhaps, slightly guilty conscience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Beaked Whale Shatters Record With 3 Hour 42 Minute Dive
description: Scientists still don’t know how the marine mammals go so long without air.
content: The 1959 movie “Ben-Hur” runs some three-and-a-half hours long. A Cuvier’s beaked whale could watch the entire film underwater, never taking a gulp of air, with time to spare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Danny Hakim
title: Judge Orders Eric Trump to Testify in N.Y. Fraud Inquiry
description: The president’s son had said he would not give a sworn deposition to the New York attorney general until after the election, but a state judge said he must cooperate sooner.
content: A New York state judge on Wednesday ordered President Trump’s son Eric to answer questions under oath before the election in a fraud investigation into his family’s real estate business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Chavez
title: Democrats, You Can’t Count On the Hispanic Vote
description: President Trump’s standing is as strong as it has ever been.
content: Democrats are counting on Hispanics to help them win the White House on Nov. 3, but they may be in for a surprise. Though I’ve been a conservative most of my life, I didn’t vote for Donald Trump in 2016 and won’t this year either. But I understand why his brand of populism and appeal to religious voters has struck a chord not just with white voters and evangelicals but also with Hispanics, who will likely make up 13 percent of voters in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Talmadge
title: Sticker Shock in the Pharmacy
description: For chronically ill patients, decisions about whether to pay or go without medications are life-or-death battles that must be fought over and over again.
content: When Caiti Derenze, a lawyer in Jersey City, N.J., went to Walgreens to refill her insulin prescription in July, she was met with a nearly $300 bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Eiffel Tower Briefly Evacuated After Bomb Threat
description: The Paris police cordoned off the area around the monument after receiving an anonymous phone call, but the site reopened two hours later.
content: PARIS — The Eiffel Tower was briefly evacuated on Wednesday after the police in Paris received a phone call suggesting there was a bomb at the monument, but officers inspecting the site did not find anything suspicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: After Storms, They Built Higher. They Dread Doing It Again.
description: The deep bonds residents have for their coastal community have been tested by three epic hurricanes. Many wonder whether it’s time to leave.
content: CREOLE, La. — Mary Canik returned after Hurricane Laura to find her hometown destroyed again. The grocery store she owns with her husband had been ransacked by a wall of water, its contents a mangled mess blown onto the gravel parking lot. Her home, which had been rebuilt after an earlier hurricane and lifted 14 feet 9 inches off the ground, was nothing but posts and a cement slab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: After Years of Political Gridlock, Oregon’s Fire Disaster Brings ‘New Reality’
description: Early this year, lawmakers considered legislation to thin forests, hire firefighters and increase building standards to prepare for wildfires. But a dispute over how to address climate change doomed the proposals.
content: SALEM, Ore. — The warnings kept getting more dire: Even in the lush landscapes west of the Cascade Mountains, the climate in Oregon was getting warmer and drier. More people were moving up into the tree-covered hills, where thick forests were poised for ignition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Oliver Sacks: His Own Life’ Review: All Was Not Well With the Doctor
description: A new documentary explores the fascinating and sometimes troubled life of the famed neurologist.
content: With his beard, his burliness, his ready smile and his clear, steady, British-accented voice, the physician and writer Oliver Sacks was perhaps the Platonic ideal of the avuncular white male genius. But as comfortable and comforting a figure as he became, Sacks, who died in 2015 at age 82, of cancer, was for a long time a traumatized, troubled man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: What Is ‘Wanton Endangerment,’ the Charge in the Breonna Taylor Case?
description: Here’s what is behind the charge leveled by a Kentucky grand jury against one of the officers involved in the fatal raid on Ms. Taylor’s apartment in March.
content: A grand jury in Kentucky has indicted a former Louisville police detective, Brett Hankison, on three counts of “wanton endangerment in the first degree” for his actions during the raid of Breonna Taylor’s apartment. What does that mean?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. Rationale for Military Aid to Saudis in Yemen War Is Fraying
description: The Trump administration argues that its partnership with Saudi Arabia helps reduce civilian killings in Yemen. But State Department investigators and other U.S. officials say the efforts are flawed.
content: WASHINGTON — When challenged over why the United States has continued to assist Saudi Arabia and other Gulf Arab nations in a bombing campaign that has killed thousands of civilians in Yemen, Trump administration officials have often responded that American involvement is helping to hold down unnecessary casualties by advising the Saudis and their allies on targeting and rules of engagement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: U.S. Ambassador to Netherlands Faces Questions About Political Interference
description: The outspoken conservative envoy, Pete Hoekstra, has been criticized for hosting a fund-raiser for a Dutch populist party at the U.S. Embassy.
content: BRUSSELS — One of President Trump’s most outspoken ambassadors has found himself in a new controversy after co-hosting a fund-raiser for a populist far-right Dutch political party in the American Embassy in the Netherlands. The act appears to breach diplomatic protocol because of its involvement with domestic politics in the host nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood
title: 2 Sentenced to Hang for Deadly Garment Factory Fire in Pakistan
description: The country’s worst industrial fire killed more than 260 people in 2012. Victims’ relatives said the real culprits had escaped justice.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Eight years after Pakistan’s worst industrial fire killed 264 people and injured 60 others at a garment factory in the country’s largest city, a court has sentenced two men to hang for arson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: 100 N.Y.C. School Buildings Have Already Reported a Positive Case
description: Nearly all the buildings remained open, following city guidelines that say only those schools with two cases in different classrooms will shut.
content: At least one coronavirus case had been reported in more than 100 school buildings and early childhood centers in the New York City school system by the first day of in-person instruction on Monday, according to the Department of Education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Hooray (Mostly) for the Government!
description: U.S. lawmakers are digging into questions about how to steer technology to make our lives better.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and John Schwartz
title: Election and Supreme Court Fight Will Decide Trump’s Environmental Legacy
description: Court losses are piling up for President Trump's environmental deregulation agenda. But a second term in the White House could help them stick.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has initiated the most aggressive environmental deregulation agenda in modern history, but as his first term drives to a close, many of his policies are being cut down by the courts — even by Republican-appointed jurists who the administration had hoped would be friendly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Christine Hauser
title: American Consumers Have Lost $145 Million to Coronavirus Fraud
description: More than 200,000 complaints of scams and fraud have been filed so far this year, data from the Federal Trade Commission shows.
content: Americans have lost more than $145 million to fraud related to the coronavirus, according to the Federal Trade Commission, which said it had fielded more than 200,000 complaints from consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: Gillian Flynn Takes Her Paranoia to Television
description: With “Utopia,” the best-selling novelist makes her debut as a TV showrunner. But anyone who knows her from “Gone Girl” or “Sharp Objects” might be surprised by what they see.
content: Gillian Flynn grew up surrounded by comics. Her father, a film professor and an avid comic book collector, would spend weekends taking her to flea markets and garage sales, explaining the various eras and artists she should know, which strip was loosely based on a Ray Bradbury story, and so on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: The Home Schoolfluencer
description: You don’t need Google Classroom, says Ainsley Arment, the founder of Wild + Free. Just nature, literature and a community of patient “mamas.”
content: Many home-schoolers feel misunderstood. People assume they’re religious adherents, hippies or anti-technologists who distrust institutions, when, in fact, they have a wide range of backgrounds and motives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Republican Inquiry Finds No Evidence of Wrongdoing by Biden
description: The report delivered on Wednesday appeared to be little more than a rehashing of unproven allegations that echoed a Russian disinformation campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — An election-year investigation by Senate Republicans into corruption allegations against Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son, Hunter, involving Ukraine found no evidence of improper influence or wrongdoing by the former vice president, closing out an inquiry its leaders had hoped would tarnish the Democratic presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Breonna Taylor Live Updates: 2 Officers Shot in Louisville Protests
description: A grand jury didn’t charge any officers with killing Ms. Taylor in her apartment, prompting protests nationwide. A former detective was indicted on three counts of “wanton endangerment.”
content: Two Louisville police officers were shot during demonstrations on Wednesday night, the police chief said, after a grand jury decided to not charge any officer in the killing of Breonna Taylor, instead indicting one former detective for recklessly firing into another apartment during the raid of Ms. Taylor’s home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch Milan Fashion Week Shows With Us

title: Getting Climate Into the Presidential Debates
description: Also this week, learning to live with smoke. And, climate experts talk about the future.
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter, and thanks to everyone who made the latest Netting Zero, our series of virtual events looking ahead to key international climate negotiations next year, a big success! The panel focused on cities trying to become carbon-neutral. If you missed it, don’t despair. You can watch a recording here.

author: By Emma Marris
title: Experts Warn a Rare Pediatric Condition May Re-emerge This Fall
description: There’s no cure for acute flaccid myelitis, or A.F.M., but early detection is key for better outcomes.
content: In the fall of 2018, all three of Mallory Bradley’s kids became sick. Her sons, aged 8 and 2, ran low fevers for a couple of days, but were soon back to normal, running around their new house in Norfolk, Virginia. Then Ryleigh, Bradley’s 3-year-old daughter, spiked a high fever, and oddly, seemed floppy and unsteady. A kid that usually ran with confidence was suddenly listing and weaving across the playroom — Bradley knew something was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Ginsburg Clerks Remember Her as a Mentor Who Treated Them Like Family
description: With birthday cakes, baby clothes, meticulous edits and high standards, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg forged a personal bond with her clerks that transcended the legal profession.
content: WASHINGTON — For the birthdays of her Supreme Court clerks, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg would often bring a cake baked by her husband, Marty, a tax lawyer and deft chef, serving it at a celebration in her chambers.
source.name: The New York Times

content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — There is a very important life lesson to be learned from Margit Christenson’s debut New York Times crossword puzzle, but I’m going to let you discover it for yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s legal to bring guns to polling places in five battleground states, a new study says.
description: Five battleground states in the presidential election have no laws prohibiting people from carrying guns into or near polling places, according to a study released Wednesday by two gun control organizations.

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Listening Closely to the Birds
description: What comprises the soundscape where you are?
content: Welcome. Pre-dawn, the sounds in the house are few and predictable: the refrigerator lurching to a hum, then off again; the steam knocking in the pipes. This morning, however, the pigeons, delirious with the expanse of dark that was all theirs, thrashed against the windows, landed with thuds on the A/C units. On purpose? By accident? I imagine them sleepy and clumsy, or else showing off to one another, their morning calisthenics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House Approves Short-Term Bill to Avoid a Shutdown
description: The measure would stave off a government shutdown, providing funding until Dec. 11.
content: WASHINGTON — The House approved a stopgap spending bill after Democratic congressional leaders and the Trump administration reached a deal on Tuesday to avert a government shutdown next week and extend funding through Dec. 11, agreeing to include tens of billions of dollars in additional relief for struggling farmers and for nutritional assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flake
title: My Kid Sold Her Soul to Roblox
description: It’s my daughter’s main social outlet, and I’m not taking it away from her.
content: I made a deal with the devil this summer. Lots of devils, if we’re going to be accountants about it. But one in particular weighs heavy on my heart: Roblox.

description: A massive market in Mexico City is emblematic of the region’s struggles.
content: No part of the world has been as devastated by the coronavirus as Latin America. Of the 15 countries with the highest deaths per capita in the world, 11 are in Latin America or the Caribbean.

description: The couple did not endorse any candidates, but Meghan called the election “the most important election of our lifetime.”
content: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, appeared in a video encouraging Americans to register to vote, dipping a toe into United States politics in a way royal family members typically avoid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Justice Dept. Urges Congress to Limit Tech’s Legal Shield
description: President Trump and his allies have made criticism of major tech platforms a regular talking point as he campaigns for re-election.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sent Congress draft legislation on Wednesday that would reduce a legal shield for platforms like Facebook and YouTube, in the latest effort by the Trump administration to revisit the law as the president claims those companies are slanted against conservative voices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America’s Health Care Is Under Existential Threat
description: A Supreme Court case could eliminate the Affordable Care Act, and the president should be judged for recklessly supporting it.
content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death could not have come at a worse time for the millions of Americans who get their health insurance through the Affordable Care Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: 356 Elephants Dropped Dead. Did This Bacteria Poison Them?
description: Some conservationists accepted the explanation provided by Botswana’s government, but others raised doubts.
content: In May and June, conservationists discovered the carcasses of 356 elephants in Botswana’s Okavango Panhandle. Some of the animals appeared to have collapsed and died suddenly, while walking or running. Others seemed disoriented, walking in circles before they died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cooper
title: The Metropolitan Opera Won’t Reopen for Another Year
description: The nation’s largest performing arts organization, shut by the coronavirus pandemic, sends a chilling signal that American cultural life is still far from resuming.
content: The Metropolitan Opera announced Wednesday that the still-untamed coronavirus pandemic has forced it to cancel its entire 2020-21 season, prolonging one of the gravest crises it has faced in its 137-year history and keeping it dark until next September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Vecsey
title: Gale Sayers Dies; Elusive Hall of Fame Running Back Was 77
description: Though his career was cut short by injuries, he was regarded as one of the N.F.L.’s greatest players. The movie “Brian’s Song” spread his name beyond the sports world.
content: Gale Sayers, the will-o’-the-wisp running back who in a short but brilliant career with the Chicago Bears left opponents, as they used to say, clutching at air, died early on Wednesday at his home in Wakarusa, Ind. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Endorsing Biden, Cindy McCain cites Trump’s disparagement of military members.
description: The widow of Senator John McCain praised Joe Biden’s “character and integrity” and noted that both he and her family had children who had served in the military.
content: Cindy McCain, the widow of Senator John McCain of Arizona, formally endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. for president on Tuesday, praising the “character and integrity” of her late husband’s longtime friend and colleague while voicing her unease with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Go Live in Another Decade. I Recommend It.
description: Watching TV news from the past helps me get a grip on the present.
content: After the 2016 election, I was deeply shaken not just by the outcome, but by the terrifying sense that I did not understand the nation as well as I’d thought I did. To blunt the shock, I went on a bender through American history. I dove into books about the Civil War, the Progressive era and, finally, Robert Caro’s titanic biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, where I washed up on the shores of the turbulent 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed and Daniel Berehulak
title: In the Epicenter of Mexico’s Epicenter, Feeling Like a ‘Trapped Animal’
description: For the vast majority of people in one teeming neighborhood of Mexico City, risking illness or death has simply become the price of survival.
content: IZTAPALAPA, MEXICO — The man in the vegetable stall next to Christopher Arriaga’s died first. A longtime customer was next, then another. A few days later, an elderly carrot vendor got sick and died within the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Pogash
title: Come to Vote, Stay for the Art
description: In California, the Institute of Contemporary Art San José will open for voting, with a mural by Amir H. Fallah on display.
content: While many California museums are still shuttered because of the coronavirus, and others are opening slowly at limited capacity, the Institute of Contemporary Art San José has come up with an ingenious solution to open the museum, legally, for four days.
source.name: The New York Times

content: As the coronavirus spread around the University of Georgia and her fellow students partied, Arianna Mbunwe, a junior, took to Twitter to call them out.

author: By Andrew Keh
title: A Girl Wanted to Try Out for Boys Tennis. Ginsburg Helped Make it Happen.
description: In the early 1970s, a law professor named Ruth Bader Ginsburg took on a case that paved the way for a 15-year-old girl in New Jersey to play on a boys’ high school team.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: Biden Could Be Our Second Catholic President. It Doesn’t Matter.
description: With John F. Kennedy in 1960, Catholic America achieved a long-sought victory. But what did we win?
content: As Election Day approached 60 years ago, Catholics across the country followed the news with a nervous thrill of anticipation. For them, the final stage of a long struggle was at hand: An Irish Catholic was poised to become president of the United States, ending the historic Protestant monopoly on the White House — and on mainstream, middle-class respectability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Three Cheers for Melissa Clark
description: Back in March, she began a column specific to the pandemic. Now it’s time to end it.
content: Back in March, when everyone was freaking out about having enough flour and beans to last through quarantine, Melissa Clark started writing From the Pantry, a series of articles meant to ease readers of The New York Times through the business of cooking more regularly and more flexibly, using what ingredients they had to hand. She did this every day, for weeks, then regularly thereafter, 60-odd recipes developed on the fly, a brilliant run of creativity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Chiarito and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: ‘All That Death in His Life’: Daniel Prude’s Tragic Journey to Rochester
description: Mr. Prude had a somewhat troubled life in Chicago, with a series of personal tragedies disrupting his attempts at finding meaningful stability.

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Jackie Stallone, Celebrity Astrologer and Sylvester’s Mother, Dies at 98
description: After running away with the circus, she promoted women’s wrestling and fitness before seeing signs of the future in a most unusual spot. (Hint: it’s not the palm.)
content: Jackie Stallone, the matriarch of a celebrity family who became something of a celebrity in her own right as an astrologer, died on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The artist and movie production designer, who brought a meticulous eye for detail to movies including “Star Wars,” “Alien” and “Back to the Future,” helped shape the aesthetics of science fiction.
content: Ron Cobb, the artist and movie production designer known for his work on the spaceship in “Alien,” the DeLorean in “Back to the Future,” and some tipsy aliens in “Star Wars,” died on Monday in Sydney, Australia.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: As China Ages, a Push to Add Elevators Offers a New Kind of Economic Relief
description: China’s premier wants to retrofit three million older apartment buildings all over the country, but he still needs political buy-in at the top.
content: GUANGZHOU, China — When China faced previous economic slowdowns, it favored pharaonic, multibillion-dollar construction projects to quickly pump money into the economy. A bullet train network that now connects 700 cities. Ultramodern expressways longer than America’s interstate highways. And 81 of the world’s 100 highest bridges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Chief Executive of Embattled Alaskan Mine Project Resigns
description: The executive made “offensive” remarks about the state’s political leaders, the company said, in meetings recorded by an environmental group.
content: The chief executive of the partnership developing the Pebble Mine in Alaska resigned on Wednesday over comments made in meetings recorded by an environmental advocacy group.

author: By Julie Weed
title: When the Classroom Comes With Room Service and Poolside Cabanas

In this study of 100 people who had Covid-19, M.R.I.’s showed at least some signs of myocarditis in 60 of them, meaning they had inflammation in the heart muscle, which can weaken the organ and, on rare occasions, lead to sudden cardiac arrest. Another study, published this month in the same journal, looked at 26 Ohio State athletes who experienced Covid-19 with mild or no symptoms and detected evidence of possible myocarditis in five of them and lesser abnormalities in nine more. author: By Teju Cole
title: In Dark Times, I Sought Out the Turmoil of Caravaggio’s Paintings
description: The work the artist made near the end of his life changed my understanding of both beauty and suffering.
content: Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio, born in late 1571 in Milan, is the quintessential uncontrollable artist, the genius to whom normal rules do not apply. “Caravaggio,” the name of the Northern Italian village from which his family came, reads like two words conjoined, chiaroscuro and braggadocio: harsh light mixed with deep dark on the one hand, unrestrained arrogance on the other. Raised in Milan and the village of Caravaggio in a family that some say was on the cusp of minor nobility, Caravaggio was 6 when he lost both his father and grandfather, on the same day, to the plague. He was apprenticed around age 13 to Simone Peterzano, a painter in the region, from whom he must have learned the basics: preparing canvases, mixing paint, perspective, proportion. He apparently developed a facility for still-life painting, and it was probably while studying with Peterzano that he absorbed the pensive atmosphere of Leonardo da Vinci and great Northern Italian painters of the 16th century like Giorgione and Titian.
